title: Simple-Minded Wisdom
content:
A "simple" character (particularly a servant or rural character) displays uncommon wisdom — usually much to the surprise of an arrogant main character. Creates An Aesop moment.

This would seem to derive from Cervantes' Don Quixote, where the archetypically "simple" Sancho Panza occasionally produces statements of great wisdom (although in that case the main character, Don Quixote, often fails to notice or credit that wisdom).

Dungeons & Dragons players will lecture, in great detail, that Wisdom and Intelligence are not the same thing.

Compare Dumbass Has a Point, which is what said Insufferable Genius may say after hearing the simple character's idea.

See also: Achievements in Ignorance, Too Dumb to Fool, Whoopi Epiphany Speech, Infallible Babble, Hanlon's Razor. Contrast Ditzy Genius, which is in many ways the diametric opposite of this trope, and Seemingly Profound Fool, in which other characters erroneously read wisdom into the genuinely banal observations of a bona fide fool.
• In the first Knights of the Old Republic, you get questions to see what kind of Jedi you'll be. None are "wrong", but guess which answer here leads you to become the wisdom-seeking, magelike Jedi Consular: There is a locked door, and you need to get to the other side. What do you do? 

1. Blast it open. 

2. Hack into the lock to get it open. 

3. Knock.
• Final Fantasy V's protagonist, Bartz, is described in the manual as a "simple wanderer." He has some Book Dumb traits, but he also has a very uncomplicated and un-angsty outlook on saving the world. For instance, when Krile's wind drake will die if not treated with a plant that only grows in a place so dangerous no one has ever returned from it, it sends the party into a brief despair, until Bartz breaks it with these words: "Guess that means we'll be the first who do!"
• Sera from Dragon Age: Inquisition occasionally makes surprisingly profound statements based on straightforward observations, stumping even the more book-smart party members. For example, when Solas badgers her one conversation too many about organizing the Red Jennies to dispose of the nobility for good: Sera: What, just lop off the top? What does that do, 

Solas: I... forgive me. You are right. What, just lop off the top? What does that do, except make a new top to frig it all up? I... forgive me. You are right.
• This exchange becomes even more tragic in hindsight after you learn Solas's backstory; it turns out that his actions against the elven "gods" in the distant past resulted in pretty much this . Twisted Metal:Head-On Cousin Eddy, a mentally deficient Hillbilly, wins Twisted Metal. Typically this is where Calypso Would grant a wish that he would oh so horribly corrupt in various ways (Most endings in the series, outside of the First game Twisted Metal 1 and the malevolent wishes in Twisted Metal: Black, are not granted as the wisher intended, and even fewer actually outsmarting Calypso at his own game.). Cousin Eddy points at his Vehicle and simply asks 'Make it better.', This after Calypso initially refusing to grant his wish due to not having been invited to the tournament (As far as this troper is aware, he is the only example of this in the ENTIRE SERIES.), and after being 'Persuaded' (And by this I mean Cousin Eddy threatens to break his neck.), he does so reluctantly. Unfortunately for Calypso, and ABSURDLY LUCKILY for Cousin Eddy, Despite the even higher than usual motivation Calypso probably had to screw him over, there's not alot of leeway in terms of alternate interpretations for "Make it better." Which forces Calypso to grant him his wish without his usual dickery. Calypso laments the turn of events in this ending.
